newsitem.title: FRANCE: Ariane gets new INTELSAT launch contract.
newsitem.headline: Ariane gets new INTELSAT launch contract.

text.p: Western Europe's Arianespace said on Thursday it won a contract to launch a satellite for INTELSAT, the 18th satellite from the Washington-based body to travel on its rockets.
It said the INTELSAT K-TV satellite would be launched in late 1998 or early 1999. It will provide video services to the Asia-Pacific region and will be built by France's Matra Marconi Space.
The satellite will weigh 3.2 tonnes. Financial terms were not disclosed and the statement did not specify whether an Ariane-4 or Ariane-5 rocket would be used.

The first new generation Ariane-5 rocket exploded in June 1996 seconds after its maiden flight from the European Space Agency (ESA) launch centre in Kourou, French Guiana, on the northeast coast of Latin America.
Washington-based INTELSAT, with 140 member nations, owns and operates 24 satellites.

It remains the world's major operator of international satellite services despite recent competition from private non-governmental providers. The organisation said 1996 revenues exceeded $911 million.

Arianespace controls more than half the world's commercial rocket launch market. It fears, however, that its lead is threatened by consolidation of the U.S. industry -- notably the planned purchase of McDonnell Douglas Corp by Boeing.
The company said it now had firm orders to launch 41 satellites worth an estimated $3.5 billion.
